dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN, good-looking, practised grin, is staring into a bathroom mirror. He is dressed only in a dressing gown. H looks at himself long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can explain it because it’s not inexplicable; it’s a logical decision, the product of proper thought. He opens a bathroom cabinet and takes out a nasal hair trimmer. He sticks the nasal hair trimmer into his nose a begins to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN now has a face full of shaving foam as he carefull shaves with a steel sharp-looking razor.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Simply put, the reason why I want to die is because I don’t want to live. And you can’t get more logical than that. He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm taking all the mystery out of it, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN walks into the living room - he’s now dressed, and dressed well.  2. He walks past pictures of children we'll later recognise his own, and pictures of him and a woman we’ll later recognise as Cindy, then there are pictures of him beside woman carrying numerous daytime TV trophies, this woman w later recognise as Penny. MARTIN picks up the letter he’s left on the mantelpiece, puts it beside the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. I’d go so far as to say committing suicide is one of the most logical things I’1l ever accomplish. He checks his watch. He exits. The camera stays in the ro MARTIN re-enters and picks up the letter he’s left by the phone. He picks it up and thinks - he puts it back on the mantelpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin steps out of his apartment block. A nice apartment block. He thinks and then returns back into it. We stay looking at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Imagine you’re an - assistant bank manager in Guildford offered the job of managing a bank in Sydney. Well, even though it’s a pretty straightforward decision you'd still think for a bit.... Maybe write a pros and cons list. He returns - struggling out, this time with a ladder unde his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the cons, aged parents who might die when you’re on the other side of the world, friends you’1l miss, and a golf club where you know your handicap is not laughed at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN lashes ladder onto the roof of his car. He does energetically and without a great deal of skill.  10

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...on the pros, more money, better quality of life, sea, sunshine, women with suntans, a chance to invent yourself as being someone other than an assistant bank manager from Guildford. He stops. He breathes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts the car. He takes a toffee from his glove compartment and shoves it into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now I’m not an assistant bank Manager, I haven’t got aged parents, they’re dead, I don’t play golf, I hate the sport... He backs it out of the drive. He drives down the street.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But eighteen months ago I had everything and then - I met Danielle Thurby. He passes a woman he knows who is wearing devil horns and embarrassed grin. She smiles. And mouths ‘Happy New Year’ waves.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Five feet nine inches. thirty-six double-D. Fifteen years, two- hundred and fifty days old and yet she looked twenty-five if a day. I didn’t even enjoy it. Her. It.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN parks up the car beside an office block which seem ascend into the sky - this is Toppers Tower. He gets out his car, looks up at the looming building for the briefes seconds, and then starts to unlash his ladder.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now my wife hates me, I can’t see my kids, I’ve a criminal record, a listing on the national sex offenders register and have so spectacularly pissed away my career that I’m less successful than an assistant bank manager in Guildford.Yup. Suicide is my Sydney.  11 12 13 14 4. He puts the ladder beside the car. He takes a bolt cutter a torch out of the boot. He clips it on a buckle to his trouser belt. He puts the bolt cutter into his back pocke where it sticks out precariously.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No offence intended to the good people of Sydney of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is waiting for the lift, it arrives. He attempts t put his ladder inside. It doesn’t fit. He tries it another way. It doesn’t fit. He tries it a third way. Yup. Really doesn’t fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN takes the stairs, carrying the ladder, the torch banging against his leg with every step. He looks up the staircase. Only fourteen more flights to go. Only - fourt fourteen - exhaustion awaits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is bolted. MARTIN is seriously out of breath. MARTIN takes out the bolt cutter. He makes to break open bolt. But the bolt has already been got to and slithers a as soon as he touches it. The door swings open effortless MARTIN puts his bolt cutter back in his back pocket. Then thinks better of it and takes the bolt cutter out of his pocket and throws it on the floor. He won’t be needing th again. He takes a breath and then walks out through the open doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof has three feet of barbed wire netting around the outside of it, with a metal strut at the edge of the wire MARTIN lays his ladder horizontally so that it traverses the barbed wire. He takes out a cigar. He tucks it behind his ear. He puts the torch in his mouth and begins to crawl out on his ladder. Over the wire. It’s a horrific and vertigo- inducing watch. He wobbles at one point, and clings on, then he steels himself and keeps going. He reaches the end.  5. He carefully manoeuvres himself into seated position. He refocuses himself. He sits as if on the edge of the world, he puts the torch his lap, he doesn’t look down - instead - he takes the ci from behind his ear and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Um. Excuse me. MARTIN turns and looks at MAUREEN, astonished there is someone else up there with him. MAUREEN is 40-something, has a brave, anxious, smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not entirely sure how to phrase this. But... Are you going to be long?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure whether to wait my turn or....I hadn’t considered the wire. I'd really like to borrow your ladder. If that’s.... There is a moment’s pause.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe I should just wait. I’1l wait.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. No. MARTIN turns back to facing the night sky, frowns and tur back to MAUREEN, his concentration gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're just going to stand there and watch are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: No. No. Of course. You’1l be wanting to do it on your own I'd imagine.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You'd imagine right.  15 16 17

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’ll go over there. She indicates the door. She begins to walk over to it. He half laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I‘1l give you a shout on the way down. MAUREEN attempts half a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Right. MAUREEN stands quietly - looking towards MARTIN and then turns around. He checks what’s she doing and then.... He composes himself. He feels the mood take him. He takes puff of his cigar. He looks out forward, maybe he even lifts himself up ready to propel himself out. And then he drops the cigar - from his mouth. And then reaches out to grab it and in doing so almost overbalance over the edge of the tower. Fuck. It’s a long way down. H grabs the edge and regains his balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cigar tumbles down the side of the building and we go with it. Turning in the night air, our stomachs lurching. drop is further and faster than we’d ever have anticipate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cigar lands with a bounce. Then it lies still. Then a truck roars over the top of it. The camera closes on a cigar lying brutally flattened on road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN wobbles, he looks down. He points the torch down. can’t see the drop. He thinks. He thinks again. He looks down. He announces.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I can’t. Not with you watching.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Oh. He looks at her, she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could leave, come back in twenty minutes... MARTIN thinks and then frowns.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Maybe you should go first? MAUREEN registers this. She thinks. She turns thoughts over in her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’d - want to be on my own. Completely. On my own.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Understood. Twenty minutes. Then I want my spot back. MAUREEN thinks and then nods.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Right. OK. He thinks and then starts crawling back along the ladder. The ladder wobbles again. MARTIN’s survival instinct come in again - he lies still a moment. He looks at MAUREEN. S puts out a hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maureen. MARTIN stands. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Are you from... I recognise your face...?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you? They realise they’re still shaking hands. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Were you married to someone in a pop group?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. MAUREEN remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you on TV? She thinks. Slightly excited now.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mushrooms. You like mushrooms.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mushrooms?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You said. I remember. There was one of those chefs in the studio - moustache - and he gave you something to taste and you said ‘Mmmm, I love mushrooms, I could eat them all day.’ Was that you? MARTIN digests this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Maureen. Perhaps now’s not the time for small talk. MAUREEN smiles at MARTIN. She looks at the ladder. She kn what this means.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Well. I’ll...um...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes...I’11 just - leave you for - Which is when they hear a door bang behind them. JESS, 18 stands with mascara running down her cheeks. She is dress for a New Year’s Eve party, high heels, the works. She lo at the two of them - confused. She sees the ladder, she frowns, and then she starts runn hard for it. She almost makes it. But MARTIN grabs her by her belt. She kicks him in the face, but he hangs on and pulls her backwards onto the roof.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: No. No! He is really having trouble keeping hold of her.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Calm down. Calm down. She wriggles away. She makes for the ladder again, this time he full on rugby tackles her. They fall to the groun with an oooof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you? JESS tries to stick her fingers into MARTIN’s eyes. She i wild on something.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Ow! Maureen. Bit of help...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: You're getting a thrill out of this aren’t you - pervert! The struggle continues, MAUREEN is anxious not to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What do you want me...to do? JESS looks up at MARTIN. She recognises him.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Oh my God. You’re Martin Sharp. You are a pervert. Officially.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: That’s it! Rise and Shine with Martin and Penny.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sit on her will you? MAUREEN hesitates, and then sits on Jess, and MARTIN knee on her arms.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Just let me go. Let me go. MARTIN turns and looks at her, amazed at her balls. Then phone begins to ring. And they look to their own phones. MARTIN stands, MAUREEN stands, JESS stands. And they look at each other. It’s no their phones ringing. The phone continues to ring. MARTIN flashes his torch aro the roof looking for the culprit. It alights on...JJ - he sitting cross-legged on the opposite edge of the tower bl He’s wearing a crash helmet and he has an insulated pizza on his lap with ‘Paulo’s Pizzas’ printed on it.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Hi. He talks with an American accent. They all stare at him. thinks and then takes off his helmet - he’s mid-20'’s, sh looking. He shuts off his phone and smiles - unsure.  18 10.

dialogues.speaker: JJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any of you guys order a pizza?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How long - have you been - there?

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I don’t - know. JESS starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Well if you’re here for the death ride ....there’s a queue. TITLES: A LONG WAY DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in exactly the same positions. JESS grins as she looks at the other three.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: So do we do introductions...? I’m Jess. People call me Jess.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’m Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Jd.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm -

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Martin Sharp.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Quite exciting to have a celebrity in our suicidal midst. The word ‘suicidal’ seems to make everyone wince.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as if it’s small talk) So - what made everyone chose Toppers Tower?  19 11. No-one says anything. JESS thinks and then takes the pizz from JJ and opens the box. She grins at the contents. She seems to be enjoying herself. None of the others are.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ham and Pineapple? Really? And it’s cold. No-one fancies jumping down and getting some pepperoni do they? No-one laughs. No-one says anything. JESS looks at them a and begins to eat.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No-one fancies a slice?.. What? Not going to deliver it now is he? MAUREEN looks at MARTIN and then JJ.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: This....this feels wrong. JJ looks at MAUREEN. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Maybe we could jump together....One. Two. Three. She makes for the ladder. But MARTIN is too quick and kic it out of the way. It falls through the wire and descends heavily to the ground far below. MARTIN watches it...anxiously. It lands with a distant smash - a car ala blares. JESS laughs. Then suddenly it begins to rain. They wait. Looking at ea other. MARTIN looks up at the skies. He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you - all. He exits the rooftop. He leaves everyone else behind. The remaining three exchange a look - unsure what to do w themselves - and the rain gets heavier still. INT. MARTIN’S CAR. NIGHT 19 MARTIN sits looking numb. He’s numb with shock. His skin a greyish pallor to it. The rain drums incessantly on the windscreen. He turns on radio. He turns it off again. He turns on the windscreen wipers - but they’re slightly broken - there’s a weird pa in the middle of their rotation - oh, and they squeak.  20 21 22 12. MARTIN just looks at the world. And then - suddenly - he hammers the steering wheel with his hand. And then he reg hammering the steering wheel. This is both raw pain and, know, slightly pathetic. MARTIN starts the car. He begins to drive. He drives past MAUREEN standing in the rain at a bus stop She disrupts the thought. He thinks. He stops the car. He looks back at her. He reverses it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN is standing fastening a carrier bag onto her head a make-shift hood.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you want a lift?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: No. No. The bus will be along in - fifteen minutes. MARTIN looks at her gruffly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Get in the car Maureen. MAUREEN thinks and then does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN looks around and smiles at MARTIN, they’re still nervous of each other.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I did like your television show. MARTIN doesn’t answer, they lapse back into silence. They drive past JJ - trying to get a Pizza moped started the rain. MAUREEN looks at JJ. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN. MARTIN stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Tonight is really not going how I expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN drives past JESS. Who is walking purposively along street.  23 13. MARTIN’s car stops. JESS runs to the car and then looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Bit early for a reunion isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Get in. We’re taking you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN is moderately dry, everyone else looks like drowne rats. They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So this is - jolly...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Maybe we should have some sort of group therapy. Right here. Right now. Maybe that’s what destiny wants. Take a right here. MARTIN does take a right.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK. One word answers. You can all have one word answers which address exactly why you were up on the roof in the first place. No-one says anything.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To give an example, Martin might say notoriety.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are you trying to get us to share our feelings? Because I’m not sure this is the best way.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: To give another example, Maureen might say loneliness. MAUREEN looks at JESS, hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Is that what you think? JESS turns to JJ. JJ doesn’t want her to turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: And then there’s our pizza boy...  14.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Jd.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I call you pizza boy-

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Pizza boy. Why might pizza boy want to die? I’m guessing -

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: What would be your reason, I can tell you’re dying to tell us?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Dying to tell you? See what he did there? No? My reason....Love. The oldest most fucking chestnutty chestnut of them all. MAUREEN turns - surprised by the swearing.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chas. He spurned me. I’m a spurned woman. (she smiles broadly) Take a left. MARTIN takes a left.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I am not lonely.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Tell that to your cats.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I don’t have cats. JESS is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Really? JJ is thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are we not fitting into your pre- ordained boxes Jess?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Actually you fill your one marvelously - was prison fun?  15.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You really believe you have an answer for everything don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I really believe you are a miserable bastard.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Actually, right now, a miserable bastard is exactly what I am. Have I not been hiding it well? MAUREEN interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I was up there because I felt...helpless.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: And I was up there because I have cancer. I have inoperable cancer. JESS smiles broadly and punches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: We have a winner. Fucking brilliant. MAUREEN turns - ready to say something about the swearing but she doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very impressed. Embarrassing cancer? JJ hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Brain. CCR.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Colon would have been better.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry JJ.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s largely self-inflicted, few too many drinks and drugs you know...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Right. Pull up here. MARTIN pulls the car to a stop.  24 25 16. They look up at the squalid house they’re outside of, the listen to the pumping music it’s emitting. There is a par going on.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Here? You live here?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: No. But Chas is likely to be here. And I’ve got things to say to him. She looks around the car.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. Good luck with your next attempts. See you in the afterlife. She exits the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands looking up at the party. And for a moment her is that of a little vulnerable girl - she takes a breath, steels herself, and enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN drives with steady intensity. The broken windscree wipers grow ever more annoying.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I should have thought... The most popular suicide spot in London on the most popular night for suicides.... I should have thought I wouldn't be...alone.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Didn’t occur to me either if that makes you feel any better. MAUREEN looks at MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Unhappy little thing isn’t she? MARTIN chooses to ignore the gentle prodding of MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where am I dropping you JJ?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know why she thought I’d have cats and she certainly swears too much. But...  26 27 17. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Go on Maureen... Just say it...

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I just...should she be alone? MARTIN stops the car. Again. No-one says anything. MARTIN sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN, MARTIN and JJ enter through a broken front door. MAUREEN looks around - extremely worried. It’s a loud and quite aggressive party. It’s full of people who look like they don’t belong anywhere but here and our three stand o like sore thumbs. JJ has to shout over the music.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Martin take the stairs, Maureen take the bathroom, I’1l take the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. I... JJ interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: What else we gonna do? JJ heads off into the crowds. MARTIN thinks and then copi JJ's bravery. MAUREEN lingers a moment more - looking immensely uncomfortable - and then follows them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN walks slightly disorientated through the crowds. This party really is a rampaging beast. He looks this way and that but this really is...he doesn’ know what he’s looking for.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hi. He tries to stop a youth moving through the room. The you looks at MARTIN like he’s pointless. He feels pointless. MARTIN tries again.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m looking for...  28 29 18. Again he’s ignored. MARTIN sits on a sofa. In the backgro we see MAUREEN edging around the edge of the room. A girl sits beside him. She looks at him and then strokes his face.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m looking for a girl called... She strokes his face again.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Jess. Do you know the name Jess? She looks at him for three seconds, and then instantly falls asleep. On his shoulder. MARTIN looks at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. Great. Perfect. Then people start chanting.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Ten. Nine. MARTIN realises what’s happening. He extricates himself f the girl and lies her down against the arm of her sofa.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eight. Seven. He aims for the exit. But he literally can’t get through. MARTIN looks for somewhere to hide. He spots a staircase. He aims up it.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Six. Five. Four. MARTIN takes the stairs two at a time. He opens the exit the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN takes several deep breaths. He really doesn’t want to be here tonight.  19. Then two people come out after him. And he looks for somewhere to hide. He wedges himself beside a sort of gri in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: PEOPLE
dialogues.text: Three. Two. One. Happy New Year. There’s an audible cheer from the house and the streets outside. There’s an audible cheer throughout London. Fireworks ignite throughout the streets. London is beautiful. The two people kiss. MARTIN winces.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey. MARTIN turns, surprised. He didn’t realise he had company CHAS is sort of sitting underneath the grill.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh. Um. Hi. Hiding too are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, sort of - I can’t come into the light.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Is that - comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You get used to it. I’ve taken some pills. All good. MARTIN laughs, he likes this guy.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you hiding from?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, you know - humans - humanity - humankind. You? CHAS’s eyes are as round as saucers.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: A nutter who is trying to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Your reason is better than mine then. And where is this - nutter?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: She’s everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She’s God-like? I see.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I'm hoping I’m just having a bad pill. But she’s not supposed to be here and I’m pretty sure I just saw her. Though I’m also pretty sure I’ve seen you on breakfast TV, so maybe...you know, I mean it actually could be a good pill and... I don’t... MARTIN looks at CHAS and then smiles softly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You’re Chas aren’t you? CHAS looks back and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: How d’you know that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m here with the - nutter. CHAS looks at MARTIN like he’s dangerous, then tries rapidly to escape. This is easier said than done. He bangs his head on the underside of the grill.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chas. Chas. Listen to me. Let’s go find her together. What’s the worst that can happen? CHAS turns to him with incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: She's tried to kill me twice, got me arrested once. I’m banned from three pubs, two clubs, a cinema, and a hairdressers...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Ok. So the worst that can happen is...bad but... CHAS stops and sways and looks at MARTIN more carefully.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Look. Just let me leave quietly. I did nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong? Taking her to bed. Nothing wrong? MAUREEN appears in the background of shot.  21.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: No more drugs for this man. MAUREEN looks at MARTIN and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: All these people - and you should have seen the toilets- MARTIN smiles acknowledgement.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I’m off -to a monkery - monastery - I’m becoming, you know, a monk.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You owe her the courtesy of talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: She won’t talk! She’ll chase me with a bread knife -

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: And tonight she was prepared to end her life because of what you did to her. CHAS wobbles. Suddenly sober. MARTIN looks concerned. But MAUREEN is determined to let her bitterness hang on.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Maureen. I think that’s a bit (much).

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: That’s where we met her. On top of a tower block. Preparing to - you know... MAUREEN is clearly very upset. CHAS wobbles slightly agai

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: What? Then JJ bursts through the doors. He looks at MARTIN, and then at MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: It’s Jess. I think she’s taken an overdose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESS is pushed hard through the hospital. She's trying to speak. She’s bucking hard. She’s deathly white. MARTIN follows the trolley. MAUREEN, CHAS and JJ two step behind.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Jess. Jess.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Are you her father? MARTIN is slightly offended by the question.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. JESS manages to get some words out.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Next of kin? Are you next of kin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. No. The trolley is moving quickly, MARTIN has to half run to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sir. I need her full name.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I only - she’s called Jess - I didn’t - none of us knew her before tonight. Another nurse is going through JESS’s pockets.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE 2
dialogues.text: She's got no identification on her. No nothing. MARTIN half-smiles, but not in a good way.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She probably didn’t want to make identification easy....I think she likes things - difficult. The NURSE looks at him coldly.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You need to wait here....  32 33 23. The hospital double doors close on the action. MARTIN stands a moment, unsure whether to force himself in behin them. He looks at his reflection in the glass of the door. He r his face.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN, MARTIN and JJ sit in a line in a green-soaked waiting room. CHAS is lying on one of the other benches. Curled up. Asleep. With a thumb in his mouth. There is a small television in the corner. Blaring out images of Hogmanay.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Do you think she...do you think she meant it? She doesn’t seem like she meant it. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How do you seem like you mean it? MAUREEN considers the question.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Well. I suppose you go through with it. This is a dark thought. It settles uneasily on the room.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: She has. We haven’t. I need some air. JJ stands and walks out. MAUREEN thinks, looks at MARTIN and then follows JJ. MARTIN thinks and then follows MAUREEN. CHAS is left alone. Curled up in foetal position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN’s car is parked in an empty car park looking up at the hospital. JJ, MAUREEN and MARTIN stand against it.  34 35 24. MARTIN gets out a cigar and lights it. He hands it wordlessly to JJ. Who takes a puff and hands it to MAUREE who smiles, doesn’t puff and hands it to MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: The rain’s stopped. MAUREEN checks her watch. MARTIN rubs his eyes and smiles

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Late for something? MAUREEN looks at him guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: My son’s home in three hours. And - Matty’s breakfast is quite complicated. MARTIN is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You have a son? MAUREEN reads his surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I don’t.... If I’m not going to die tonight it’s important he doesn’t know anything - happened. MARTIN nudges MAUREEN, she sees what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESS is coming out of the fluorescently tinged hospital, dressed in a gown, wearing nothing on her feet. She sees them looking at her. She pulls a dance move. Saturday Night Fever style. Then she coughs. Then she starts to walk towards them. She walks a little like John Wayne. They watch her approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands and looks at them a beat. Looked at closely sh has charcoal smears at the corners of her mouth. She smil at them all.  25.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: OK. So a few things to clarify. One my gown is open backed because they’ve stolen my clothes, so I’m going to twirl so you can look at my arse once. She twirls. We get a look at her arse.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But please don’t look again. It’s not my best feature. I’m not telling you what that is until I know you better. Two. It wasn’t an overdose. It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Jess...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I just took some pills - for fun - and then took some more...I’d never kill myself with pills - jumping off a tower block is way - way - cooler. And then she laughs, but no-one else laughs. Jd We were worried Jess. Her face grows more serious. She looks at JJ.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: That’s four. Three. Four. I’m losing count. Thanks. For, you know, caring ....appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He was worried, I was trying to work out why we were still here.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: And that’s five. Four. Five. Oh, fuck numbers... I’ve been thinking. We’ve gone too far. We need to make a pact.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: And six. Is it just me or is it fucking cold out here?  36 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN, JESS and JJ sit beside a vast open airport-style window looking out on a London vista. MARTIN approaches them carrying two coffees and two cokes stops a moment, looks at them, thinks and then carries on towards them. He sets the drinks down. JESS grabs one of the cans and o it.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: When’s the next date? After New Year's Eve? When every one kills themselves?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why - ?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Valentine’s Day. JESS looks at MAUREEN and smiles, that is a good answer.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: That’s six weeks. Here’s the pact: No-one kills themselves until then. There's a brief silence as everyone tries to digest this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why? Why would we do that? Why would we not kill ourselves if and when and how we want?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Because we’ve met each other now - because - you stopped me - twice - you Martin. But mostly because - JESS thinks, she’s trying here. She starts to play with t salt and pepper pots in front of her - almost acting out scenario.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know that bit in films where people fight up the top of the Empire State building - and there’s the bit when the baddie slips off and the hero tries to save him, but the baddie’s sleeve rips off and you hear him all the way down. Aaargh.  27.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You want to watch me - plunge to my doom?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I'd like to know I’ve made the effort. I want to show people I’ve made the effort. There’s a silence. A soft tissue silence.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides, what’s the alternative? A race to finish. Me checking the obituaries every week to see if Martin Sharp is dead... She looks at JJ and MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No offence, your deaths won’t make the papers....Think about it. It’s only six weeks. MAUREEN is thinking hard. She looks at JJ, who’s thinking too, and MARTIN, who’s frowning.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: It isn’t so ridiculous. And...no- one really knows how I feel except you three so...well.. Just ‘til Valentines Day. I’d like that. JESS turns and smiles at MAUREEN, surprised at her ally.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Thank you Maureen! Who’s got a pen? JJ gets out a pen.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paper? MAUREEN thinks and pulls out a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Paper. JESS speaks as she writes in a faux posh accent.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: The undersigned do hereby promise not to kill themselves until Valentine’s Day. Maureen sign... MAUREEN nods and signs.  28.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pizza boy sign...

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Just do it. You’re dying anyway. Makes no odds to you. JJ thinks, hesitates, looks up at them all as if about to something, and then changes his mind and signs. JESS signs after him.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then there’s you Martin...life saver. Superman. The two hold eye contact for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s only six weeks. We’1l all push you off the top ourselves at the end of it if that helps... Bea little Valentines’ Day treat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure we’re going to live to regret this. JESS grins. MARTIN signs.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Guys. Look. JJ indicates - the sun is coming up. Breaking low over th London landscape. They all turn and stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (soft, so soft) So it is a new year then?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. And the four stand together looking up at the dawn sky.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Hang on. Maureen..... Just a fucking question here... JESS has unfolded the piece of paper which they’ve writte their pact upon. MAUREEN turns towards her.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have we written our pact on your suicide note?  37 38 39 29. MAUREEN blushes and then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. There is that. JESS laughs first. Then MARTIN. And then everyone laughs. And properly. And then they stop. Because it sort of isn’ that funny. But the smiles remain.

dialogues.speaker: C/U. FINGERS. DAY 37
dialogues.text: A hard and heavy pumping beat. This world is visually and rhythmically different to the world we’ve been in. If Martin’s soundtrack was Bruce Springsteen then we’re now the land of Tinchy Stryder.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It surprised me to hear that invisibility is a technical possibility.

dialogues.speaker: C/U. FINGERNAILS. DAY 38
dialogues.text: They're badly chipped and covered in three chipped layers different coloured nail polish - gold, silver and red. They're carefully applying lip salve to a set of lips. JE own lips.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was in this book that Chas owned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESS walks down a street. Like she owns it. She has the purpose of an SAS soldier on a secret mission. Her phone begins to ring. She looks to see who is calling She walks into the middle of the road. She disconnects th call. A car slams on its breaks to stop from hitting her. It be loudly. JESS turns, looks at it aggressively, and then ra her top and flashes her bra at the aggrieved driver.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can’t remember the theory exactly. It was something about defracting light. Good word. Defracting. Chas didn’t really understand it. I didn’t either. But, you know, good to know, I think, invisibility being a technical possibility.  40 30. Her phone rings again. This time, it has ‘The Minister’ o it. She looks at it, frowns, and then disconnects. She looks up, breaks into a small run and then slows down She IS on a mission.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not that I’ve ever wanted to be invisible. But sometimes - I don’t like to be seen. We follow her POV - she’s watching a man walk down the st holding a guitar case. He turns and looks towards her. JESS dodges behind a bin. He turns into a small pawn shop. JESS follows him.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I follow them all...Not just him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on a bench, obscured by a pillar, watching JJ through the glass of a pawn shop display window.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s important to me - everyone sticks to the pact. You see the thing about me is I’m very contractual, by my very nature. JJ hands over his guitar and takes money in return.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s a trust thing, and, according to my fifth therapist - who I tried to stab with a letter opener - I have slight trust issues. Someone sits on the bench opposite her. They open their newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I follow them all. Just to - check. The front cover reads ‘TV’S MARTIN SHARP IN SUICIDE BID WITH MINISTER'S DAUGHTER’ . JESS looks at it. Frowns. Then her phone starts ringing again. She looks at it. She answers it.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: OK. To clarify. Now I know why you're ringing... 4l EXT. RIVERBANK. DAY 41 JESS approaches a middle-aged man in a suit. CHRIS who is reading a large newspaper. She sits beside him. She puts on a Russian accent.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: The Pink Flamingos fly North on Tuesday. CHRIS puts down his paper and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: And the Bengali Tigers will eat them at Christmas with Worcester sauce.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Jess.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Top spy location Dad. Hugely - inconspicuous.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Look, we have a - this is a - situation...so I’ve invited... JESS's eyes go dead.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: A “situation”? That’s the word you're choosing is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: How else would you refer to...it?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I don’t know Dad. CHRIS looks at his daughter for a beat, then dismisses th thought.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You did what you did.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: ...Tried to kill myself.  32.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Tried to....Are you going to twist my words all day? Because this is hard enough. JESS'S face grows cold.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Is it? Sorry Dad. JESS starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. Jess. Jess. JESS bangs hard into a man coming in the opposite directi

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Will you fucking watch where you’re....oh. It’s MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Uh...I was invited. A Junior Minister’s daughter - I was surprised. JESS turns to look at her Dad who is now standing behind

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: You were invited?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I called his agent. So we could all talk -

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: You called his agent? JESS turns back to MARTIN. She truly is piggy in the midd

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He was delighted. First call he’d had in a while. Was it you - who went to the press? JESS scowls.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: No. You think I'd want this? I’ve been trying to work that one out myself.  33.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Too shy. Maureen? MARTIN’s face answers that one. JESS has a despairing thought.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chas. Fucking Chas. It was Chas. He sold us. MARTIN nods - that makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: My ex-wife rang this morning - asking what I’d done - asking me what she should tell the children.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I’m going to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Who’s Chas?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She told me I seem to be the only person in the world that the press gets bang on. If they say I’ve slept with a fifteen year old, I generally have. If they say I’ve contemplated suicide, I generally have. CHRIS is looking at him, the words ringing loud.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I read about that with the - girl...You didn’t....you two aren't...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Oh God. You're asking whether we've slept together aren’t you? MARTIN looks at CHRIS - who is this guy? He starts to lau

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Jesus! Really? You think I’d -

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Oi! I am at least legal.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah and I value our friendship too much to complicate it.  34. JESS raises her finger at MARTIN’s irony. CHRIS smiles relieved.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Which is an interesting - area - um, will you maintain a relationship with Jess? MARTIN smiles an incredulous smile.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Of course he will, we’re in a gang.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We're not in a gang.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: We signed a pact.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Ah yes, the pact, I almost forgot. He turns to CHRIS with a weary lack of enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jess and I are friends for ever. JESS looks at MARTIN - angry at his sarcasm. CHRIS sits o bench. He looks at his daughter, and then back at MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Martin...I’m sure I don’t need to tell a man with your media training that this is a firestorm... JESS looks at them both coldly. She puts on a faux posh voice.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is a media firestorm. Gentlemen. I’1l leave you to it. JESS storms off.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Jess. Jess. Jess! Come back here! JESS turns around violently.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Why don’t you invite him to my therapy sessions? Or - better yet - our family therapy - maybe you can pay him to be you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Martin doesn’t want my money.  42 35. He looks at MARTIN.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you? I mean... MARTIN barks a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t even have this in our house?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The press will be there. I was trying to protect you! JESS looks at her Dad - furious - and then continues away through the trees - running this time - a jogger has to d out of the way she’s so determined - CHRIS doesn’t chase.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jess. Walking away solves nothing.. But she’s long gone. MARTIN and CHRIS stand uncomfortably looking up at the empty space JESS has left.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did that go as badly as I think it did?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Has anyone ever told you, you’re a bit of an idiot? CHRIS smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m a politician. No-one ever tells me anything but. MARTIN thinks and then thinks again. He looks at CHRIS coldly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sort your own mess out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESS leaves the park - her face full of fury.  43 44 45 46 36. EXT. JESS’S HOUSE. DAY 43 JESS walks up to her very plush town house but has to pus her way through a gaggle of reporters to do so. Easier sa than done. As she passes and disappears into a throng of press, a reporter talks direct to camera.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: This is the second tragedy for the Crichton family after the disappearance of older sister Jennifer two years ago. The throng moves as a blob as Jess tries to move through We travel inside and see her fighting for air, both liter and metaphorically. REPORTER (0.S.) (CONT’D) Jennifer was never found. And you have got to wonder how shadow Education Secretary Chris Crichton will cope with this new strain upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESS is lying on her bed. Her bedroom is decorated how you’d imagine Jess’s bedroom might be decorated. She begins to gently sing the words t Tragedy by the Bee Gees (but she knows the Steps version)

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Tragedy. When the feelings wrong - There is a knock at the door. JESS turns towards it. The knock is repeated.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I come in? JESS says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS knocks again on the door.  47 48 49 50 51 52 37.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jess. Jess? Shall I come in? Shall I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS enters JESS’s room, with hesitancy. His face sinks. He looks around the room. He talks almost under his breat OPEN WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Where have you gone now? Jess... EXT. JESS’S HOUSE. ROOF. SUNSET 49

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jess... JESS sits on the roof. It’s the side of the house. The reporters are visible, but only just, and they can’t see JESS listens intently as her Dad gives up and leaves. She looks down at the drop beneath her. She sings. Again. Under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Tragedy. When the feeling’s wrong and you can’t...la la la.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has gone. Streetlights now shine out. A wideshot of the reporters below and - well, just visibl JESS remains on the roof. Waiting for - waiting for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESS walks quickly along a street. She checks her hand. S has an address smudgily written on it. EXT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. DAY 52 JESS approaches a small suburban Council house. She check her hand again - she rings on the doorbell.  53 38. She waits. MAUREEN answers the door. INT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY 53 JESS is amazed, MARTIN and JJ slightly uncomfortable (tho they've clearly been here longer and have their coats off MAUREEN looks shyly tentative.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Yes, this is Matty...My son.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: No. Really. Wow. You’ve wowed me.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Jess... Cut wide and MATTY is sitting in a special chair in the centre of the room. He is 22 and has severe cerebral pals and severe (related) learning difficulties. He is almost entirely incapable of speech or movement.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t - I don’t - what does that mean? Wow?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I mean - wow - this what you were hiding in here!

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Jess. Enough. JESS turns and looks at JJ. Surprised at him telling her Then she looks back at MAUREEN, who is visibly upset.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
