dialogues.text: Still, she fucked you, right? So at least she’s thorough. JESS thinks and then walks back and leans in and kisses J the cheek and then she exits. And JJ stands and sways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JJ sneaks carefully back into the room and opens KATHY's He searches inside it. He pulls out a digital recording device. And the blood drains from his face. He rewinds it presses play. He hears himself.  97 98 99 77.

dialogues.speaker: JJ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: - a bunch of desperate people being desperate together as a way of feeling less - desperate. She snuffles in bed beside him. He presses stop. He looks her carefully. And then edges up the sheet so as to look her left inner thigh. There is nothing written on there. scars. Just the soft skin of a woman that knows she’s beautiful. He stands. He walks. Carrying the recorder with him. He shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JJ sits on the floor by his hotel room. A night porter walks by. Singing a song. JJ tries to hear what it is, he can’t make it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is just rising as JJ stands in front of the sea. Carrying the recorder with him. He hurls it into the water as far as he can. Then he thinks and then follows it in. He walks into the water. Then he swims. He swims and he swims. The hard swim of someone looking f something. He stops when exhausted. Unsure what to do next. And the camera pulls back - on a confused guy in the midd of a big lot of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN stands in the middle of the buffet breakfast. He’s clearly very hungover. The breakfast is eat as much as yo can and everyone is indulging. As such, around MARTIN is constant movement but he’s entirely still. MARTIN’s eyes fixated on a kid sticking his hand into a chocolate fount Every so often the kid removes his hand and licks it. Chocolate is going everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think it’s sweet.  78. MARTIN doesn’t turn to acknowledge MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think it’s unsanitary.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: No. Only part of you thinks that, the other part thinks it’s sweet. MARTIN looks at MAUREEN - surprised at her confidence.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you waiting here?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for them to finish that tray of scrambled egg and bring in a new tray. I want the fresh stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: The scrambled egg is never fresh Martin. I may not have been on many holidays before but I have been in a lot of hospitals and I understand institutional catering. MARTIN looks at her, his frown deepens.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Who are all these people? And why do they eat so much?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: They're having a good time. That’s all. MARTIN thinks and then looks at them all. MAUREEN smiles softly at him. She touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for arranging this holiday Martin. I think it’s been good for me. MARTIN turns to her surprised. His eyes darken.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You really don’t understand how much of a disaster we all are do you? MAUREEN looks at him, smiles, and then takes his plate fr him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Come-on. Let’s get you some breakfast.  100 101 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JJ stands in the corridor of the hotel. He looks through some double doors. He thinks. He’s psych himself for something. He runs his hands through his hair. He sits in one of the hotel seats. He thinks and then walks through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JJ walks through the buffet bar and spots MARTIN, MAUREEN JESS sitting together. He takes a breath and then joins t JESS looks at him and smiles softly.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Hi. MARTIN follows JESS’s eyeline and notices JJ.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good morning JJ. May have said some stupid things last night. Drink has never been my friend. JJ stays standing.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Yeah. So... I’ve got a few things to say. And I’m not sure you’ll like any of them. All three look up at him - surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Are you going back to America? JJ takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I'll start with the biggest: I’ve not got cancer of the brain. I've not got CCR.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: They’ve cured you? JJ turns and looks at MAUREEN bravely.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I never had it. I made it up. Beat.  80.

dialogues.speaker: JJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s not even any such thing as CCR. Just - Creedence Clearwater Revival are one of my favourite bands.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Oh. They’re beyond shocked. JJ looks at JESS.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I wasn’t going to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You knew about this?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I thought there was - something strange about -

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So why were you - up there - JJ? JJ hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: He can’t answer that. It’s personal.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’m sure he had good reasons.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did he? JJ - did you? JJ notices KATHY approach across the restaurant. This is wrong timing. MARTIN stands and approaches JJ.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Guys. We’re going to need to postpone this conversation for another time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We made a pact - I - trusted you - I liked you. JJ looks at KATHY, almost at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Please. Martin. Sit down. We'll do this another time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Another time? What time? KATHY thinks whether to kiss JJ, but decides better not.  81.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Where were you? I woke up, you’d gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh right, so we all stop for your girlfriend do we? JJ looks at MARTIN. He doesn’t want to say this.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Martin. She’s not my girlfriend, she’s a journalist. There is an anguished pause. KATHY realises she’s rumbled

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She’s - what?

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Shit. This is..

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You don’t seem to know much do you?

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Martin. Please. This is all wrong. MARTIN’s face grows horribly cold.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It is - all - wrong isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: If he didn’t know, he didn’t know. We've had bad things written about us before - we’ll have -

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I understand you being angry, but please Martin...I’m feeling pretty humiliated here...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You don’t understand anything. You certainly don’t understand humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Martin. You’re being dramatic. MARTIN pushes JJ against a table. Full up with anger.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You’re a fraud JJ. A leach.  102 82. JJ pushes MARTIN back.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I’m not a fraud.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: John. This is not what...

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is John? JJ looks at JESS.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I’m John.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You didn’t even tell us your real name! MARTIN pushes JJ again.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Martin. Stop this. Remember the pact.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Oh fuck the pact. She swings and hits KATHY. Who isn’t expecting it and dro like a stone.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: My nose... JJ turns to look at this just as MARTIN punches and conne with JJ's ear. JESS fights with KATHY and MARTIN fights with JJ. And it’ not good, but it’s not farcical. It’s more reckless than that. We close on MAUREEN - watching - this is hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch as our four glide past us on the travelator. MAU has no noticeable physical damage, MARTIN has a blackenin left eye, JJ a blackening right, but it’s JESS that licks plate clean - with two eyes firmly black. No-one is looking at each other. In fact, no-one is looki at much at all. They’re all thoroughly consumed by what a mess this has been.  103 104 105 106 107 108 83.

dialogues.speaker: C/U. FEET. DAY 103
dialogues.text: Two feet dangle, and then have tights pulled over them, a then they’re placed in shoes.

dialogues.speaker: C/U. SHOES. DAY 104
dialogues.text: The feet - now in their sensible shoe sheaf - shift from side to the other. INT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. MATTY’S BEDROOM. DAY 105 MAUREEN carefully puts MATTY into a hoist. She hoists him of bed, he dangles in the air and she carefully guides hi down into his chair. Around him are silver mobiles and glimmers of light.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not having Matty with me on the holiday - it felt like I was missing a leg. Strange. Light. INT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY 106 MAUREEN carefully attaches a nozzle onto a feeding tube i MATTY’s lower stomach. Then she turns on a machine which begins to pump food through the tube.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s probably not like missing a leg at all. I don’t imagine most people's first impressions of leg loss is weightlessness. INT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY 107 MAUREEN and MATTY are watching TV. It’s full of colour an quite frenetic. Neither of them are.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I missed him most when the plane was landing. We shook a little on descent. I thought I was going to die.. INT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. MATTY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 108 MAUREEN tucks MATTY in.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I hadn’t said goodbye.  109 110 111 112 113 84. INT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. BEDROOM. DAY 109 MAUREEN stands in front of the mirror. She tucks in her tummy. Looks worried at the reflection. Checks her hair. Despairs of her hair.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: JJ's girlfriends’ piece meant the story - our story - didn’t die - and so the press still followed me - but I concentrated on being boring, like Martin said. Not difficult. EXT. MAUREEN’S HOUSE. DAY 110 MAUREEN leaves the house carefully pushing MATTY.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And as for the others... As soon as we landed - we scattered in different directions like we were - allergic - to each other. The pact was broken beyond repair and without the pact - our friendship was broken too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN pushing MATTY’s chair into the Church. She carefu lights a candle. She notices JESS dodging behind a pillar

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I still saw them - patchily - every now and again. I saw Jess in places she shouldn’t be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN looks into ‘Paulo’s Pizzas’ where JJ pulls pizzas of a hot oven and loads them into boxes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I did make a little effort to find JJ - just to check he was OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN drives past MAUREEN pushing MATTY on the street. S has a new haircut. It suits her better. He notices her, s doesn’t notice him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never saw Martin.  114 115 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN pushes MATTY down a corridor. There is patient ar the walls.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. Mostly I got on with my life, and hoped they got on with theirs. She stops by a notice board. On the board is a poster wit detachable segments on the bottom. It says ‘Do you have t answers?? Join The Patient-Staff Quiz Team’. MAUREEN looks at it for slightly longer than is necessary

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN stands with MATTY in front of her at the poolside There is a younger child with Cerebral Palsy in the pool being carefully led through exercises.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: Matty did great. We did some interesting reflex work.... MAUREEN looks at MATTY and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Nice to have him properly looked after for once.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: ..-He reacted well to company.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’m sure he loved a change from my blathering... MAUREEN is unpicking everything.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: .--And we couldn’t get him out of this pool.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He’s always liked water. No pool at my house. DR STEPHENS looks up at her and frowns, desperate to contradict her, but he can’t think how.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: Well...I was very pleased to have the opportunity to spend some time with him.  116 86.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I think the pleasure was all his.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: There might be a slot for him to come to my weekly sessions if you'd like it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’m sure he’d love it.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: I’1l add him to the list. DR STEPHENS has exhausted all he has to say. They sit in silence for a beat too long. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) You look like you caught a bit of colour... MAUREEN blushes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Did I? Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: You enjoyed yourself? MAUREEN considers this and looks up with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Yes. I did.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: From the pictures in the papers it seemed you picked a very nice location... MAUREEN blushes and smiles at DR STEPHENS.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Yes....Well, I won’t keep you... She stands and bustles and begins to sort MATTY out. Then turns, worried she’s been rude.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for your help Dr Stephens. We’re very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN pushes MATTY along the street. A kid stops and stares at MATTY. The kid’s mother pulls h away.  117 118 87.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Oh. No. No. MAUREEN walks on. She stops and traffic lights and presse the ‘wait’ button. The green man starts flashing. She just stands there. We watch the green man slowly flick off. INT. MATTY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 117 MAUREEN is giving MATTY a gentle bed bath, carefully deal with the difficulties of his limbs. MATTY keeps knocking the water. Splashing her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What is it? MATTY splashes again. MAUREEN (CONT’D) Matty.... MATTY knocks the water again. She’s splashed again. Then the doorbell rings again. And MATTY gives up, exhaus

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Matty... Then the doorbell rings again, and MAUREEN puts down the water. And beginning to rub MATTY quickly dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN answers the door. She doesn’t know the person on other side.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You're wet. MAUREEN looks down at herself and realises she is.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry to have called so late - it was an impulsive decision to visit.  88.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Right. Who - are you? CINDY barks a nervous laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I’m Cindy. Martin’s wife...Ex-wife. MAUREEN looks at her a moment, digesting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You better come in. 119 INT. MAUREEN’S LIVING ROOM. NIGHT 119 CINDY tries to think where to sit, she can’t decide, she waits for MAUREEN to sit first. MAUREEN doesn’t sit.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Do you want a cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: No. No. I’m fine. MAUREEN sits uncomfortably. CINDY picks up a photo from beside her chair.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This your son I’ve read about?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Matty.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Looks like a nice boy. MAUREEN nods. CINDY looks at MAUREEN carefully.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven’t heard from him in weeks. Every time I ring he puts the phone down. And I need to know he’s OK. When Martin falls off a cliff he really - falls off a cliff. MAUREEN is hugely uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s why you - I’m sorry, I haven’t seen him - since we came back from holiday. CINDY digests this.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: What’s he - told you about me?  89.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Not much. He’s a very private man.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: He’s not private. He’s secretive. There’s a difference. This comes out more aggressively than CINDY intends. MAUR retracts her neck slightly.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Has he told you I won’t let him see his kids?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He did say that. CINDY is pulled tighter than a guitar string.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Of course he can see his kids... He just doesn’t want to. MAUREEN turns and looks at her - shocked.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You know, I’ve very good reasons to be angry with him so...I don’t know why I always have to be the one trying to mend... Sorry. Sorry. I promised myself I wouldn’t do this. MAUREEN looks at her. CINDY is crying slightly.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My kids need their Dad. And I need to know he’s OK. MAUREEN offers CINDY a tissue. CINDY takes one.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Better take two - they’re the supermarket value kind. They mush when exposed to water. CINDY laughs, despite herself, and then takes two. Then t and looks at MAUREEN cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Why were you up there? On the - roof. It’s a stark question. MAUREEN thinks about asking for clarification. But she doesn’t.  120 90.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Without me, social services would pay for Matty’s care. The standards they... He wouldn’t have to have me getting everything - (wrong)

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You think he’d be better off without his mother?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Not his mother. This mother. CINDY tries to think how to rationalize this, she can’t. stands up.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: This was a bad idea. Wasn’t it? Me. Coming here.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Was it?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I wanted you to tell me someone was looking after him. I hoped you were. But why would I expect you to help? You were up there too. CINDY begins to exit then stops. She turns - she looks at MAUREEN a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for the tea. She exits. MAUREEN is left alone.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I didn’t make you tea. INT. MATTY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 120 MAUREEN is dressing MATTY in his pyjamas. She unknots his arm to get a pyjama top on to him. He doesn’t resist. He doesn’t make a noise. She forces the top on to him. It’s not an easy business.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think you’re saying something to me. Then I realize you can’t. She sits back.  121 122 123 124 91.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe I’1l just sit here a bit. INT. MATTY’S BEDROOM. NIGHT 121 MAUREEN wakes sitting in exactly the same seat. She clear fell asleep there. MATTY is asleep on the bed. She reaches out as if to touc him, but changes her mind. She stands. She is slightly unsteady on her feet. She walks to the door. She exits. And then she re-enters at speed. She checks MATTY’s breathing. Then she checks it again.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: No....No..... She puts an oxygen mask on him, she begins to administer A lady who we haven’t seen much action from at all is suddenly all action. She opens a phone with her mouth. Sh dials 999.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATTY is pushed along a corridor. NURSES and DOCTORS administer what they can as he moves. MAUREEN runs beside them, totally at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN stands lost, desperate and limp as surgeons administer on her son. Outside the window, snow begins to fall. A NURSE guides her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUREEN sits on the chairs. It’s early morning. Around he life lives. Maybe it speeds by. Maybe we watch people being wheeled i gurneys and people shouting at vending machines. And drun coming in and out. It’s clearly snowing outside, many loo snowed on, and a familiar sludge forms in the entrance wa  125 92. MAUREEN stands and walks slowly through them to the phone She begins to dial. And priests sit beside her, and breast-feeding Mums and k with angry faces... And then MARTIN enters, looking flustered. He has fresh s on him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I came as quickly as I could. MAUREEN looks at him - glassy eyed. Emotionless. He hugs And it feels odd because these two lonely people are not to hugging - the hugging is pain and emotion all at once they both sort of sink into it. And then JESS and CHRIS enter and just - watch the hug, slightly uncomfortably. They too have snow on them. MAUREEN looks at JESS - and breaks from MARTIN - slightly astonished.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You came too?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Nothing on the TV. This is my Dad. He drove me. He’ll probably say something moving about loss now. Everyone looks at CHRIS expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear about your son Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Not one of his better attempts.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’m really pleased - I’m really - grateful - you’re all - here. JESS looks at MAUREEN - steadily.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Fuck off. Of course we’re here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. MARTIN and CHRIS sit together. MAUREEN slightly apart. JESS enters with a tray of hot chocolates which she distributes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This isn’t tea.  93.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I know. It’s hot chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I asked for tea.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Yes. But I was buying. And I don’t like the smell of tea.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So when you buy rounds in pubs..?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Ya-huh. Everyone gets pink gins. And then I never have to buy a round ever again. Clever right? MARTIN smiles. She looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is Double J still not here?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I didn’t get through to him. He’s probably not picked up his messages.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Either that or he doesn’t care. One or the other. MARTIN looks at CHRIS.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I genuinely don’t know how you've survived her...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Ear plugs.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: I’m going to make you go and sit in the car in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Ear plugs and Pink Gin. MARTIN looks at CHRIS and softly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He wasn’t the reason I was up there. Matty. He wasn’t. The tone suddenly shifts.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No.  94. MAUREEN looks at them all wildly.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: There were lots of reasons why I was up on that roof. You once asked me why Jess and I said I felt helpless. But the truth is, I hadn’t done a list for living and a list for.... It was a feeling not a.... thought. But not one of those reasons - was that I didn't love my son. Not one of them. Not one.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Maureen. We know that. For once in her life JESS has been sincere. And it’s nice And then DR STEPHENS appears at the end of the waiting ro and walks slowly towards them. But only MAUREEN notices. And then everyone notices. DR STEPHENS makes eye contact with MAUREEN - she assumes worst.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Oh no. Oh no. No. Don’t tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: No. No. He’s fine. Maureen. Maureen. He’s fine. MAUREEN looks up at DR STEPHENS.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: We're going to keep monitoring him but he’s no longer critical. He’1l be fine.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He'll be fine?

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: He'll be fine. MAUREEN looks at him, and her face feels upside down, she not sure how to look. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) Would you like to come see him?  126 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATTY is lying with lots of tubes sticking out of him. MAUREEN and DR STEPHENS stand at the front. JESS and MART behind. CHRIS behind them.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: The tubes look worse than they are. We'll remove some tonight. The rest will hopefully be out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I should have seen it sooner. If he’d had proper care. If he’d had proper care. DR STEPHENS smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: Maureen. You saved him. He looks at her. She sits beside MATTY, he thinks about leaving but decides to stay. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) It was a myocardial infarction. He had a heart attack. Of sorts. His symptoms were almost invisible. I didn’t notice it, I was monitoring it and didn’t... But you caught it. You saved his life. He stops talking. MAUREEN is gently - quietly - singing t MATTY without even realising it. She realises she’s singing and stops. Immediately. Embarrassed. She looks up at DR STEPHENS who smiles gentl back. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) It’s lovely the way you look at your son. MAUREEN looks up at him - what does that mean? DR STEPHEN ploughs on. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) He’s calmer when you’re around. You make him - calmer. He seems to - he always knows you’re there. Matty is a very lucky boy to have you. CHRIS takes JESS’s hand. JESS lets him. MAUREEN doesn’t know how to take this at all. MAUREEN tur and looks at DR STEPHENS.  127 96.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I only had one thought - when he - if he dies, I die. DR STEPHENS looks her straight.

dialogues.speaker: DR STEPHENS
dialogues.text: Well. He lived. DR STEPHENS makes to exit, and then stops. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) And maybe he feels the same way about you as you do about him, have you ever considered that? MAUREEN doesn’t move. DR STEPHENS exits. He nods at MARTI he does. DR STEPHENS (CONT’D) Make sure you don’t crowd him. He’1l need lots of rest. MARTIN nods. DR STEPHEN’s exits. MAUREEN stares intently at her son.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Are you calmer when I’m here - are you calmer...? JESS looks at MARTIN, a tear rolls down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN, CHRIS, and JESS stand in the corridor, gathering themselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well, that was....

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Then a porter comes past pushing a ‘Happy Valentine’s Day decorated trolley.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Valentine’s Day?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: No-one send you a card? Pretty girl like you....shame. JESS’s brain churns through all the possibilities.  97.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: It’s Valentines Day. Martin. It’s Valentines Day. MARTIN turns and looks at her. It’s not registering.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God, breakfast TV really mushed your brain didn’t it... MARTIN’s face drops.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: The pact.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Get Maureen. We need to find JJ. Now. 128 INT. CHRIS’S CAR. DAY 128 JESS sits intently staring through the screen. They’re driving fast through the sludge and the snow of a cold wi day. CHRIS looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The things Maureen said about her son.....

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: No time for an emotional now Dad. Things to do. People to save. But CHRIS is emotional.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to try harder Jess. I’m going to try harder, OK? JESS says nothing. CHRIS looks at her again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There was something in an article I read recently - about a man who survived jumping off the Golden Gate Bridge. He said that two seconds after jumping he realized there was nothing in life he couldn’t solve - apart from the problem he'd just given himself by jumping off the bridge. He looks at JESS.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think - do you understand that - does that make sense to you?  129 98. JESS says nothing. And then turns to her Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Yeah. It could make sense. A tear leaks down JESS’s face.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Didn't you think - ? With my face in the front of the paper ...That she'd see it and come home... CHRIS’s face suddenly is filled with pain. He battles har keep this emotion from his youngest daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe she’s dead. Maybe she just had enough of us. Maybe she - I don’t know - maybe we need to concentrate on ourselves for a bit. He parks up outside Paulo's Pizzas.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. We’re here. JESS looks at the door and then back at her Dad. She kiss him on the side of the cheek and then exits at speed. INT. PAULO’S PIZZAS. DAY 129 JESS races in ahead of CHRIS. She looks at the faces. PAU big and hairy is preparing an order - shoveling tomato on pizza bases.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: JJ? We're here for JJ.

dialogues.speaker: PAULO
dialogues.text: JJ? He’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Gone? Shit.

dialogues.speaker: PAULO
dialogues.text: Prick left a week ago. Didn’t even serve notice. CHRIS looks at PAULO. He puffs up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The “prick” is my daughter’s friend Paulo. And you’1ll do well to recognise that fact. JESS grins despite her worry. Then CHRIS loses his nerve.  130 131 99.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are called Paulo, right? PAULO approaches them both and CHRIS really loses his ner

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just the place is called Paulo's Pizzas and...you certainly sound Italian and look Italian...not that there’s an Italian ‘look’... You’re quite scary close up.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Come on Dad.... They race out together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GLADYS walks puffily up the stairs. MAUREEN follows her.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: I’m not supposed to...

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’ve been in the paper with him.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: I know you have love.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Then you know we know each other. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Such a nice boy. GLADYS thinks and then opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is in a total mess. MAUREEN looks at it. Aghast

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Oh my. Along one wall is a series of newspaper cuttings. They ha headlines like ‘No Angels here’. They are of other suicid from Toppers. They present a very bleak picture. We close MAUREEN’s eyes as she takes it all in.  132 133 134 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN walks up the stairs. He quickly gets out of breath But he forces himself on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is bolted. This time with heavier locks. And a s saying ‘Access Prohibited’. And this time MARTIN doesn’t a bolt cutter.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Fuck. He kicks at the door. The door swings open. The bolt has already been got at. Again. MARTIN looks through the door. And only then does he real walking back out on that roof is one of the hardest thing he’1l ever do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN walks onto the roof. With bravery we haven’t seen him before. He looks around the snow filled rooftop. Flak still joining it from all sides. In fact, up here, it’s a of a blizzard. Through the white, MARTIN sees someone standing on the ed of the roof. He’s heart broken.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I hoped you wouldn’t be up here. JJ doesn’t turn around.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: You know, three people have killed themselves off this building between New Year and today? Sue Chalmott, housewife and manic depressive, David Frommet a banker who'd lost everything, and Ben Peterson, he was only 15. I cut out bits on them in the local paper.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So you're going to - join them?

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: I kept to the pact. This - me - it’s none of your business now.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: True.  101. MARTIN thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One question though - why? JJ thinks - and then thinks again - and then turns and lo at MARTIN, still on the edge of the building.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: That's the thing, I didn’t lie to you - I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You - don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don’t - know. And that’s why my reason is better than any of yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Better? I wasn’t aware it was a competition.. MARTIN starts to walk towards JJ.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Jess - she just needs to feel important. Maureen - she needs to feel loved. You need to grow a brain.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s not - fair...

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: But me...I’m Dorothy... so how do I get better? What cures me? You can solve your problems. Me? I can’t. MARTIN keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: JJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Martin - stop walking. You stop walking right now. Otherwise I’1l start walking, OK? Three steps backwards. And I’m - gone. MARTIN stops walking. MAUREEN comes through the rooftop door and makes to speak She sees the scene and doesn’t. JJ doesn’t see her.

dialogues.speaker: JJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm bored of being scared all the time and not knowing why. Bored of trying to change - and not knowing how. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JJ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leaving my latest shit band, moving countries - because however much I do change I’m left with - me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sounds like you've got it all worked out JJ. It’s logical. The reason why you don’t want to die is because you don’t want to live anymore, it’s quite simple, right? JJ says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. I used to think like that too. JESS suddenly bursts through the roof doors.

dialogues.speaker: JT..66
dialogues.text: MARTIN turns and silences her with a look.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And then there were four. JJ looks at JESS, he really didn’t want her here. Jd Don’t you get it - we’ve got to Valentine’s Day and nothing - absolutely nothing - has changed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: But - everything - has changed.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: We're standing in entirely different positions for one thing. JJ wobbles. He looks at JESS. He wobbles.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And the rest of us - the other three up on this roof - we’re not here because we want to die - we’re here for you. He looks around the rooftop.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to be up here ever again JJ. I’m pretty sure none of us did.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: He’s right. It is shit up here.  135 103.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: But I am here - we are here. Now. For you. And I’m pretty sure - if you thought about it - you’d do the same for me...for any of us.. MARTIN digests his own words. JJ says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Topper House Four. We belong together. We’re a team. We’re the worst team the world has ever known and, if I’d have been picking, none of you would have even made the subs bench but still, we’re a team. JJ looks back at the edge of the tower. We look at the edge of the tower. It’s a long way down. And it’s very very white. He turns - he looks back at MARTIN, JESS and MAUREEN. MAR speaks softly to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not much I know son. But - maybe we're a start. JJ opens his mouth, considering carefully what to say. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: You can’t even see to the bottom. We look down again into the white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN parks up his car. And lets his kids - MAISIE and P out of the back. POLLY is carrying a doll. They run excit towards the park. MARTIN follows. There is evidence of sp on the trees.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Maisie, don’t run. Maisie. MAISIE does run. She falls - she scrapes her knee.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t cry. Don’t cry. You’ve just learnt a valuable lesson.. MAISIE does cry. MARTIN helps her clean up her knee.  104.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s hard not to consider the notion that I didn’t mean it. The suicide. That none of us meant it. But I did - mean it, I know I did - I scored very highly on Aaron T. Beck’s Suicide Intent Scale. Twenty- one out of thirty points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN with MAISIE on his shoulders and POLLY holding han beside him walks through a park. POLLY is talking excited

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: And then we saw a penguin and Mum said that the penguin is - a nice animal and I said it didn’t look nice.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, suicide had been contemplated more than three hours prior to death, yes, I -- was certain of death even if I received medical attention. It’s fifteen storeys high, Toppers. Yes, there was preparation for the attempt: ladder, bolt cutters, cigar... It’s just these - people - showed up. And I - well, I... He approaches a picnic rug. On it is JESS, MAUREEN and - They look pleased to see him. They’re mid conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Brilliant. I bet Martin will be good at this.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: (to MARTIN) Don’t even join in. MAUREEN looks at a child who’s approached her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Now - are you Maisie or Polly? And would you like a toffee?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What will I be good at? He sits down.  105.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Consider this... Sitting around here. Are other people who’ve - without doubt - contemplated suicide. MARTIN turns to his daughters.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Run off and play.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: But Dad -

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Now. They do.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks Jess.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: (to MARTIN) Don’t engage. Never engage. JJ grins and takes some pills out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Oh, JJ's getting upset. He’s taking his mad pills.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Anti-depressants.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I’ve bought a thermos Martin. Would you like some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: It’s true. Statistically, at least one person on this hill will at some point in his or her life kill themselves...Maureen told us, it was in her quiz book. MAUREEN blushes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I've joined a team. Just a - small thing. This matters to MAUREEN but no-one else really registers fact.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: So - who would you pick? JJ laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s where you were going with it!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Who would I pick?

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: To die.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Who would I pick to die?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s not a hard question. I think that lady. MAUREEN points out someone walking her dog. The lady noti and frowns. Everyone looks at her - shocked. A drop of ra falls from the sky.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Maureen!

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Maureen. I love you. Jd She’s looking. Put your hand down.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What? She doesn’t know what I’m saying. I could be saying who’s got the nicest bottom. It could be a compliment. JESS is delighted. She indicates. More rain falls.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: And I say that man - that man in the khaki shorts. Martin. Your turn. The man turns and looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: OK. Now everyone’s looking.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm not picking.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Martin, it’s just a game.  107.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Maureen, I’m shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Isn’t it brilliant? I’ve ruined her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: If you're shocked by that John Julius - I can do considerably worse - I’ve remembered my joke about Vaseline. It suddenly starts raining quite heavily. They start to gather their things.

dialogues.speaker: JESS
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: JT
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: The clouds part? Maybe God hates you after all Maureen. Everyone laughs as they put the ground sheet over their h and run for cover, gathering Martin’s children as they do

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, there was logic in what I wanted to do. I wanted to say goodbye to a semi-functioning digestive system, a criminal record, a wife who hated me, a job I was shit at and a more than healthy dose of self disgust - I wanted to say goodbye to a life mislaid. No. Not mislaid. That implies accidental damage. I hadn’t mislaid my life, I’d...spent it. Everyone scatters from the hill top. And then MARTIN runs back up - alone - to collect the doll Polly left behind.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But now, if it doesn’t make me sound like a dickhead, I’m going to earn it back.

dialogues.speaker: JESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It does make you sound a bit like a dickhead.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thanks Jess.  108.
